Your data set index seems to be `DatetimeIndex`, but your `fh` is a `PeriodIndex`, which is not the same, and there is no "obvious" coercion.

Is that the issue, possibly?

If so, this highlights that there should perhaps be a more informative error message.

Was it that, @Data-drone? Please confirm.
If not, would appreciate a reproducible example.

PS, @Data-drone: the workaround for version 0.7.0 is to:

* construct the `fh` with `is_relative=False` before passing to `predict` - this will no longer be required in 0.7.1 onwards
* ensure `freq` is set in all `DatetimeIndex` of yours, and the same
How do I set freq with a `DatetimeIndex`?

Well, you can set it in the constructor when you create it, as outlined in the examples in the [pandas doc](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DatetimeIndex.html).
So, for instance `myindex = DatetimeIndex(sthsth, freq="D")` for daily frequency.

You can also convert a `freq`-less pandas object using the [`asfreq` function](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.asfreq.html).

If you post your code (doesn't need to be with the original data frames), happy to help you modifying it.

An alternative would be to just use integer/range index instead - this quick hack would be to just to drop the index entirely, if it's equally spaced, using `reset_index(drop=True)` - you'd then have to calculate back to days.

Hm, but this code doesn't create a `DatetimeIndex`? It just creates an index.
The reason is that non-pandas `datetime` can confuse the integration with `pandas` objects.

To ensure you get a `DatetimeIndex` with `freq` defined, you should preferably work with `pandas` objects and do sth like

```python

tt = pd.date_range("2013-08-01", "2013-08-05")
df = pd.DataFrame(t2, index=tt)
```

this will even automatically infer the `freq` to be `"D"`, which you can check by typing
```df.index```

Without letting `pandas` infer the `freq`, you would write it as:
```python

tt = pd.date_range("2013-08-01", "2013-08-05", freq="D")
df = pd.DataFrame(t2, index=tt)
```

well, there's no way for `sktime` to know whether you want to use the indices in the `ds` column or the actual data frame indices, so this would be a case of "reading your mind" which I don't think there is a good automation for.

But, on the other hand, I think the discussion around `freq` has highlighted some very useful insights, i.e., what to do if `sktime` sees a `DatetimeIndex` with no `freq` attribute. Guess we can make that more user friendly by automatically removing the index and interpreting it as equally spaced.

Okay so the workflow for me should be:

- Read in the data set from Spark
- Split the data into my train / validation dataset
      - The plan is to do sliding window and or expanding window cross validation with the train set then get final metrics on the 
         validation set

- Create the date_range objects by selecting `min()` and `max()` from my date column and create pandas `date_range` objects 
   with them

> [...] what to do if `sktime` sees a `DatetimeIndex` with no `freq` attribute. Guess we can make that more user friendly by automatically removing the index and interpreting it as equally spaced.

tldr; Being able to pass the freq explicitly would have my preference.

I am not exactly sure what you have in mind, but I imagine that ignoring the index and interpreting the data as equally spaced could effectively shift around data in a way that would result in an incorrect application of seasonal periodicity (for training data) or intended horizons (for testing data). In my experience, a `DatetimeIndex` with no `freq` attribute is often a time series with either some missing data points (missing an index) or duplicate data points (having equal indices), with some of them not even being missed (or used), depending on the model and the seasonal periodicity.

If you want to handle such cases without throwing back an informative exception to the user, I think the user should be able to pass the intended frequency to sktime explictly (even with priority over the freq from the DatetimeIndex) . You might then consider reindexing internally using `date_range` and the `min()` and `max()` of the original index (i.e. introducing NaN values for formerly missing indices, but I'm not sure what happens to formerly duplicate indices). Especially for training data, you could also consider imputing missing data points and weighing duplicate data points to avoid models tripping over them.
